verb suppose to be the case, without proof.
take or begin to have (power or responsibility).
begin to have (a specified quality, appearance, or extent).
take on or adopt (a manner or identity), sometimes falsely. Middle English assumen, from Latin ass≈´mere : ad-, ad- + s≈´mere, to take; see em- in Indo-European roots.From Latin ass≈´m≈ç ("accept, take"), from ad- ("to, towards, at") + s≈´m≈ç ("take up, assume").

dictionary/words/assumption.html.title: assumption
dictionary/words/assumption.html.description: /…ôÀàs åm(p) Én/From Middle English assumpcioun, from Medieval Latin assumptio ("a taking up (into heaven)") and Latin assumption ("a taking up, adoption, the minor proposition of a syllogism"); see assume. noun a thing that is accepted as true or as certain to happen, without proof. the action of taking on power or responsibility. verb Middle English assumpcion, from Latin ass≈´mpti≈ç__, ass≈´mpti≈çn-, adoption, from ass≈´mptus, past participle of ass≈´mere, to adopt; see assume.Middle English (in assumption(sense 3 of the noun)): from Old French asompsion or Latin assumptio(n- ), from the verb assumere (see assume)

dictionary/words/dictionary.html.title: dictionary
dictionary/words/dictionary.html.description:
/Ààd…™k É…ôn(…ô)ri/early 16th century: from medieval Latin dictionarium (manuale) or dictionarius (liber) ‚Äòmanual or book of words‚Äô, from Latin dictio (see [diction].Definitions:
Noun a book or electronic resource that lists the words of a language (typically in alphabetical order) and gives their meaning, or gives the equivalent words in a different language, often also providing information about [pronunciation], origin, and usage.
a reference book on a particular subject, the items of which are typically arranged in alphabetical order.
Computing a set of words or other text strings made for use in applications such as [spellcheckers].

dictionary/words/erudition.html.title: erudition
dictionary/words/erudition.html.description:
noun Deep, extensive learning. synonym: knowledge.
Learning; scholarship; knowledge gained by study or from books and instruction; particularly, learning in literature, history, antiquities, and languages, as distinct from knowledge of the mathematical and physical sciences.
The act of instructing; the result of thorough instruction; the state of being erudite or learned; the acquisitions gained by extensive reading or study; particularly, learning in literature or criticism, as distinct from the sciences; scholarship.
Profound knowledge, especially that based on learning and scholarship. From Latin eruditio ("an instructing, learning, erudition"), from erudire ("to instruct, educate, cultivate", literally "free from rudeness"), from e ("out") + rudis ("rude").The word "erudition" comes from the Latin eruditio, meaning "learning," which is a noun from the verb erudire, meaning "to instruct" or "to educate". This Latin verb is a compound of e- ("out") and rudis ("rude," "unskilled," or "rough"), so erudire literally meant "to free from rudeness". Therefore, erudition is the result of being "taken out of a rough or uncultivated state" through a process of education and learning. 
Latin roots: erudire = e- ("out") + rudis ("rough," "unskilled").
Literal meaning: "To free from rudeness" or "to remove coarseness".
Figurative meaning: The process of educating or instructing someone, leading them from a state of being "rough" or unlearned to one of polished and extensive knowledge.
Modern usage: The noun "erudition" refers to the deep, scholarly knowledge that results from this process.

dictionary/words/index.html.title: index
dictionary/words/index.html.description:
/Àà…™nd…õks/late Middle English: from Latin index, indic- ‚Äòforefinger, informer, sign‚Äô, from in- ‚Äòtowards‚Äô + a second element related to dicere ‚Äòsay‚Äô or dicare ‚Äòmake known‚Äô; compare with indicate. The original sense ‚Äòindex finger‚Äô (with which one points), came to mean ‚Äòpointer‚Äô (late 16th century), and figuratively something that serves to point to a fact or conclusion; hence a list of topics in a book (‚Äòpointing‚Äô to their location).
noun Something that serves to guide, point out, or otherwise facilitate reference, especially.
An alphabetized list of names, places, and subjects treated in a printed work, giving the page or pages on which each item is mentioned. Middle English, forefinger, from Latin; see deik- in Indo-European roots.From Latin index ("a discoverer, informer, spy; of things, an indicator, the forefinger, a title, superscription"), from indic≈ç ("point out, show"); see indicate.

guides/guiding-methods/study-the-meaning.title: Study the meaning of the words
guides/guiding-methods/study-the-meaning.description:
Once we learn a language, we can use the words, the main building blocks of a sentence, effortlessly. But there is often much more to a word than what we know on the surface level.Human language is said to be 'messy' and ambiguous, context dependent, and not nearly as 'precise' as a formal language, like a programming language. The conversation with a friend, or this page will not crash if I make a semantic (meaning) or syntax (grammatical) error. Still, a lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. A lot of words have their original roots in Latin and Greek.Studying these aspects of the words can provide new, useful insights, improve our mastery of them, etc. listing the keywords
Dictionary definition
www.wordnik.com
guides/guiding-methods/study-the-meaning.sourcePath: guides/guiding methods/Study the meaning of the words.md

guides/guiding-methods/the-5-w's-and-1h..title: The 5 W's and 1H
guides/guiding-methods/the-5-w's-and-1h..description:
The 5 W's are a foundational information-gathering framework used in journalism, research, and problem-solving to ensure a comprehensive understanding of a topic. They consist of: Who? (The person or group involved)
What? (The event, action, or subject)
Where? (The location)
When? (The time or date)
Why? (The reason or purpose) Often, a sixth question, How? (the method or process), is added to this set to create the "5 W's and 1 H".

guides/guiding-methods-and-techniques.ht.title: guiding methods and techniques
guides/guiding-methods-and-techniques.ht.description:
Dictionary method /Ààm…õŒ∏…ôd/ noun Origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‚Äòprescribed medical treatment for a disease‚Äô): via Latin from Greek methodos ‚Äòpursuit of knowledge‚Äô, from meta- (expressing development) + hodos ‚Äòway‚Äô. Definitions: a particular procedure for accomplishing or approaching something, especially a systematic or established one. the quality of being well organized and systematic in thought or action Disclaimer: this 'list' will change massively as we go on, as the new things we learn and discover using these guiding methods will recursively change the process itself. The list here will have the TLDR version with more details in the full articles.Doubts, Issues
Even though I read up on it and have the page technique vs. method, I am still debating whether to call these methods or techniques, but for now I do not want to get bogged down. I will just dump everything here and specify, disambiguate later as needed. It's probably okay to call these methods, because the specific implementations will be the different techniques. I am listing, documenting these methods and techniques here to serve as reference and as a growing framework for thinking and analysis to progress the ideas.I plan to organize and categorize these and perhaps even build a few sequential lists (like the one below) that have a flow.As a first, self recursive guiding method let's have:
Keep in mind, check and develop the guiding methods you have We have used words, English words to articulate, note and document this first guiding principle. If the words make sense to you, good, it means we made an intelligible sentence. Words and writing are a very very powerful tool.
Inspect your base assumptions
We are not starting everything from 0, all the time. Whatever we do, whenever we communicate we make a number (innumerable) assumptions. This has an important function to keep things efficient, but there can be disadvantages, and in this case serious ones. But what exactly does the word, assumption mean?
Study the meaning of the words A lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. The Contexts it is used in, it's Relateds, Synonyms, etc., it's Etymology (origin) can reveal new aspects and insights that will make thinking and documentation more effective and precise.
Make the methods actionable They are useful as text, but they will come alive as code. To keep in mind the guiding principles, methods, set up reminders and other mechanisms, make them as built in, integrated as possible.Of course this has to be elaborated much more to become robust. But let's start by defining some words that we have used so far.
index
welcome
guide
assume
assumption
15 Properties: For any concept, try to feel which of the 15 properties is close to it. For example, I might say, that the Pattern Break is Roughness. Acceptance: Accept that you don't know what this is, you do not know the shape of the 'problem' and maybe you never will ‚ôø Accessibility: How accessible is the thing? It is no use, if it is not, or very difficult to access. ‚ú® Actionable: think about and implement things as code, action, etc. so they are not dead and static, but alive, dynamic and part of the stream and fabric of Life. Analysis, Elements: Keep track of that are the element, constituents of the systems at play, in use, and see what kinds of fields they generate. For example the words, sentences in text, the colors of an image, etc. üß∞ Arsenal, use it fully: use all the tools, elements, etc. available to you. For examples all symbols, Unicode, Emojis, components, Colors, Sketches, plugins, etc. Asimov: be as clear and precise as possible. It is not easy, and people underestimate this. Base Assumptions: take a step back, zoom out, be honest and try to articulate what your base assumptions are ü•æ Bootstrapping: Is this the same as Self Recursion? üèÑ Browsing, surfing freely: kind of like the Catalogue example. üìî Catalogue, menu, read it: Sometimes it helps just to browse the whole thing, look at all the items, for later reference and random ideas connections, without looking specifically for anything. Change of Scenery, Environment üìã Checklists: While usually very dry, this a very basic and powerful technique and can be combined with many other. Compare Entities:
For example to properly name and categorize, besides the Dictionary definition method, also compare the words and terms. for example: technique vs. method üåê Consilience: everything should be connected and the traversal should be natural Continuous Improvement üî£ Creative language, symbols: just like how locals and natives name different plants and animals based on some traits, so that the names themselves contain these traits, we should not be afraid to invent words, language to define specific Centers, Concepts in order to build new tools for thinking, and to avoid the confusion (conflation?) with existing concepts in the mental landscape/mindscape. üìñ Dictionary Definition: Study the meaning, origin, etymology and relateds of words you use. ‚ÅâÔ∏è Doubt, Question, Skepticism: it does not cost you anything to ask questions, have doubts and take skeptical positions. Environment: inspirational (books, things), comfort, relaxed?, lighting, which room, nature, peace, quiet, no possibility for interruption Examples: Always provide examples, especially for abstractions, abstract descriptions. It can be really painful when there is an elaborate description, but even just one well placed example could illuminate Free Association: aka Braindump, just release your train of thought. Guiding Methods: List the methods that are most relevant to you. Guiding Principles: contemplate what foundations motivate you Holistic approach: not only the product is important but all aspects around it in all dimensions and directions (like this list itself) üïâÔ∏è Icons, Symbols: If you really had to pick, what icon or symbol best represents the thing. ü•¢ Itadakimasu: Japanese be thankful, grateful for the resources, food, energy you use, consume, which passes through you, keeps you alive üöô Journey over Destination: there is nothing wrong with getting to the destination, but make sure it does not damage the experience of getting there. Kanban: Japanese üóø Landmarks, Monuments (Strong Centers): There have to be places, entities that stand out, and around which other entitles are organized. The ASCII Shadow section markers I place in source code, so I can see them on the minimap for better navigation and breakdown. Learn from History: at least learn that we don't learn from it! üóÉÔ∏è Levels of scale, stepwise elaboration, : all representations should be gradual, zooming in-out should be natural (like this point itself) Rule of 3: three levels of scale next to each other Icon (Emoji), Title, Description 3 levels of indenting (max) üåÄ Lifecycle: everything has a lifecycle, so it is a common pattern that can help with analyzing, understanding, learning üéì Literacy: What level of literacy is needed to understand the thing? How accessible is it? üõ†Ô∏è Manage the Methods: I don't like the word 'manage', but it best encapsulates the creation, maintenance, cleanup, etc. add new methods when you do something that is not on this list if there is any chance that it is not a one off thing (and even then it might be valuable) üó∫Ô∏è Maps: Provide a map whenever possible. It is great for navigation, overview and also provides a level of psychological comfort by knowing where you are, where can you go and how to get there. Meditation: calm, compose yourself, re-center Metaphors: Metaphors are a formidable structure and a powerful tool for discovering patterns, connect ideas, and ferry existing insights across domains. Mindset: should try to achieve, strive for the appropriate mindset that best first your current activity, creative, production, inspiration Mind your Balance üî∞ Minimalism: be conservative with space and energy (for ease of maintenance, storage, access, complexity, utility) Mottainai: Japanese üé¶ Multi-media, multi-view: why not provide all functions, views, representations for everything? Video, Text, Transcript, Audio, Presentation, etc. Natural abilities: Tap into the natural abilities of the Person üçÖ Nutrition: use different states of nutrition (hunger and fasting are not bad) Organization: better organized, for easier access, manipulation, transformation, communication, storage, backup Origin: study the origin and etymology of things, words, names, concepts, people, etc. üîÄ Pattern Break: Mix it up sometimes ü§î Personal Experiences and Examples: It is easy to get carried away with abstractions that while interesting, are distant from you. See if you have personal experiences and examples that can connect you and ground the concept. üíæ Preservation: constant backup, preservation, conservation Pros and Cons: üÉè Random: take a chance sometimes, random page, random note, etc. üó∫Ô∏è Relativity: Many things are only knowable in relation to other things. For example: Where are you? You can say a name or other identifier, but if the other party is not familiar, you will have to explain in terms of other places. üëì Review: the relation of everything to everything Rewatch, re-read, etc. periodically, you might learn, find something new, see things in a new, different, better light üìç Save for later: Keep things that you do not understand yet, but feel, have an intuition that will be important or valuable, and might come back to in the future
‚ôªÔ∏è Self-Recursion, Self Reference: Check if self recursion is in any way applicable to what you are doing. For example check the definition of the word: word What other examples and sub-methods, sub-techniques? learning about learning notes about notes trash the trashcan thinking about thinking The possibilities are almost endless Another example is when the LLMs were made to reflect on their own thinking, which supposedly improved their performance. üí§ Subconscious: let your mind work on it in the background while you use your consciousness, focus and attention for more immediate matters üåÑ Survey the surrounding Environment: You will have more confidence if you not only know your immediate, but also your surrounding environment. For example know the synonyms of a word, related fields in a discipline, or literally, what neighbors a physical location. üî≠ Switch points of view, perspectives: try as many as you can, contemplate and compare them, understand the differences
‚ùì The 5 W's and 1H: Who, What, Where, When, Why? How? Try different structures: cyclical, linear, tree, branching, networked Unfolding: everything should be foldable stepwise, in a natural beautiful way (like Origami), from one point, to complete multidimensional, explorable space üé® Use Colors Use Language üìü Use your circumstances: lean into your gifts, abilities, genetics, knowledge, power, wealth, etc. üîÄ Version control: know where you left off, see the evolution, try forks

guides/guiding-principles.html.title: guiding principles
guides/guiding-principles.html.description: principle /Ààpr…™n(t)s…™pl/ late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin principium ‚Äòsource‚Äô, principia (plural) ‚Äòfoundations‚Äô, from princeps, princip- ‚Äòfirst, chief‚Äô. a rule or belief governing one's behaviour. morally correct behaviour and attitudes. a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behaviour or for a chain of reasoning. a fundamental source or basis of something. a fundamental quality determining the nature of something. A guiding principle is a fundamental, core belief or value that directs an individual's or organization's decisions, behaviors, and actions. These principles serve as an internal compass, providing a framework for consistency, ethics, and strategic direction regardless of changing circumstances. Behind every action, activity, there seems to be a guiding principle, process, a source, even if we don't realize or cannot articulate them. But being aware can provide a powerful framework.

questions/how-do-we-learnÔºü.html.title: How do we learnÔºü
questions/how-do-we-learnÔºü.html.description:
Dictionary learn /l…ôÀên/ become aware of (something) by information or from observation. To fix in the mind or memory; memorize. To become aware or informed of; find out: synonym: discover. To gain knowledge of or skill in through study, instruction, or experience. Keywords awareness information observation mind memory memorize discover knowledge skill study school instruction experience teach intelligence
pattern method: list the keywords Core Beliefs learning is the way for the Universe to get to know itself, shape itself this is one of the most fundamental questions for us, humans to understand Metaphors Training Information Analysis Checklist
Dictionary definition
The 5 W's and 1H The definitions listed in the Dictionary are a good staring point, they are the tip of the proverbial Iceberg and only scratch the surface.The word learn, abstraction it represents, and the strong societal associations with it make it a bit more difficult to see through or underneath clearly. What growth and training is to the body, learning is to the mind? Still, even learning is embodied Learning is the exchange of the subject, Center and it's environment Learning is the informing/outforming process between Centers. What is learning? What can be learned? Why do we learn? How easy is it for knowledge to spread? How easy is it to learn? How does information reach us? Environment Intelligence Knowledge Note-taking Practice Training Memory Memorization method: [[list associations]] The Witness James Burke videolog James Burke - Connections: How easy is it for knowledge to spread School Schooling Learning, Teaching things that do not come naturally? Indoctrination Instillation of information, of teaching A specific doctrine observation books reading test mistake proof pleasure discovery power Environment intelligence patterns What can be learned? pattern recognition activation all else is the activation of these patterns ingraining pathways information software, the brain, the slate which can be erased, but traces can also remain, and be etched deeper and deeper outformation: the field effect generated by the informed entity with every step, every quantum of change The entity (center) changes the field effect changes the effect exerted on the other centers changes which straw breaks the camels back? reference name location word name information writing speaking moving technique mannerism location idea a 'facility' (crying, rolling, walking, reading) Can an embryo be said to be learning while it is growing, developing? Learning-Knowledge Is the result of Learning: Knowledge? What part does note-taking play in learning? this is a more abstract aspect, kids, children do not need notes to learn, the copy, imitate movements, sounds, mannerisms, words, etc. And these are done over and over again, because the sources, examples are also constantly present (probably), the people, family members primarily, other interactions, and also TV and other media, cartoons, etc. that is on this plane, level (showing people, etc.) These structures stick seemingly easily, but why? genetics: it is in our programming immersion: But What training is to the body, learning is to the mind?

garden
/Àà…°…ëÀêdn/ Middle English: from Old Northern French gardin, variant of Old French jardin, of Germanic origin; related to yard2. cultivate or work in a garden. a piece of ground adjoining a house, in which grass, flowers, and shrubs may be grown. ornamental grounds laid out for public enjoyment and recreation. a large public hall. I decided to try this form of publishing as it aligns the most with my way of thinking (at the moment).It's purpose is to use it as a means of documenting, publishing (sharing) my thinking about a couple of initiatives I am trying to realize.I hope it will help to force me to think very carefully about the ideas I am trying to develop, about the words I use, and the thoughts I publish.
https://maggieappleton.com/garden-history - Maggie Appleton's wonderful A Brief History & Ethos of the Digital Garden.
https://www.eastgate.com/garden/Enter.html - One of the early Hypertext Gardens.

guides.html.title: guides
guides.html.description:
guide
/…° å…™d/ late Middle English: from Old French guide (noun), guider (verb), of Germanic origin; related to wit2. One who shows the way by leading, directing, or advising. One who serves as a model for others, as in a course of conduct. To direct the course of; steer.
inspirations (divine guidance)
guiding principles
guiding methods and techniques

index.html.title: index
index.html.description:
/Àà…™nd…õks/ late Middle English: from Latin index, indic- ‚Äòforefinger, informer, sign‚Äô, from in- ‚Äòtowards‚Äô + a second element related to dicere ‚Äòsay‚Äô or dicare ‚Äòmake known‚Äô; compare with indicate. The original sense ‚Äòindex finger‚Äô (with which one points), came to mean ‚Äòpointer‚Äô (late 16th century), and figuratively something that serves to point to a fact or conclusion; hence a list of topics in a book (‚Äòpointing‚Äô to their location).
This is the main page, because every site needs one.Me

welcome.html.title: welcome
welcome.html.description:
welcome /Ààw…õlk…ôm/ Old English wilcuma ‚Äòa person whose coming is pleasing‚Äô, wilcumian (verb), from wil- ‚Äòdesire, pleasure‚Äô + cuman ‚Äòcome‚Äô. The first element was later changed to wel- ‚Äòwell‚Äô, influenced by Old French bien venu or Old Norse velkominn. Received with pleasure and hospitality into one's company or home. The state of being welcome.
Welcome to my mind garden (mind mapping, 2nd brain, etc.) experiment. It is in the form of a digital garden.Disclaimer: Let me emphasize, this is an experiment both in it's form and content. While this format has it's advantages at the moment, I really wish there were better, more humane ways for expressing such intellectual experiences. Creating such a new medium is among my dreams.
Some of my aspirations: philosophical
understanding The Universe (Reality, The World, whatever you wanna call it), because I am in awe at the phenomenon of existence, life, consciousness and want to feel at home and be fully connected both 'intellectually' and 'spiritually' making improvements and leaving The World a better place (one where I'd like to be constantly re-born) practical finding ways to practically apply Christopher Alexander's theories found in The Nature of Order, into everyday life Living Structure 15 Properties Structure Preserving Transformations because I believe these ways of seeing the World are more correct, and will supersede the current, predominantly mechanistic worldview realizing The Glass Bead Game (described in Hermann Hesse's book of the same name), because in my interpretation, conception, it would be one of the highest forms of Communication, Understanding, Art and honestly it would be a super fun to experience. I believe there may be People who suffer, because this instrument has not yet been created and therefore cannot express themselves to the highest degree (just imagine, if the piano was not there in the time of Mozart).
participating in projects that help make learning, computing and thinking tools more humane. describing a Theory of Note-taking, because I believe this is a neglected, underdeveloped aspect of human thinking and even with all the current technology, it is not living up to it's potential. becoming fluent in Japanese. ...
Some of my beliefs (I guess my base assumptions, in a way): When I read Christopher Alexander's The Nature of Order, I had a worldview shift, and since then I completely ascribe to the view, that every part of space has a degree of Life (as opposed to segregating 'living' and 'dead' things) and Wholeness (aka. Health) and that it is our duty and responsibility to learn how this structure emerges in Nature so that we can be an extension of Structure Preserving Process, the Structure Enhancing Process. I believe the process of Nature is to create Beauty and the accompanying Consciousness to experience it. Learning is the process that 'facilitates' this. It is the way for Nature to Sense itself. Does it make sense?
Some questions I ask myself (very high level):
How do we learnÔºü How does information reach us? How are we informed? How are we outformed? What is the theory of Note-taking? What is the Nature of the Universe?
Now that we put some aspirations into words, what will be our guides?
inspirations (divine guidance)
guiding principles
guiding methods and techniques

words.html.title: words
words.html.description:
Dictionary word /w…ôÀêd/ Old English word, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch woord and German Wort, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin verbum ‚Äòword‚Äô. a command, password, or signal. something spoken or written; a remark or statement. even the smallest amount of something spoken or written. one's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person. a basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
